fitting-lines-and-curves-to-edges.text: Fitting lines and curves to edges

pageProps.body:
Lec 9

Second moments of a region

  • to find the parameters λ1\lambda_1λ1​ and λ2\lambda_2λ2​, we use second moments
  • we take a window WWW centered at a pixel, and compute 3 parameters
    • a=∑i∈W(Ixi)2a = \sum_{i\in W} (I_{x_i})^2a=∑i∈W​(Ixi​​)2 - sum of intensity in x-direction
    • b=2∑i∈W(Ixi2∗Iyi2)b = 2 \sum_{i\in W} (I_{x_i}^2 * I_{y_i}^2)b=2∑i∈W​(Ixi​2​∗Iyi​2​) - sum of product of intensities in x and y direction
    • c=∑i∈W(Iyi)2c = \sum_{i\in W} (I_{y_i})^2c=∑i∈W​(Iyi​​)2 - sum of intensity in y-direction
  • The length of the parameters, semi-major axis λ1\lambda_1λ1​ and semi-min axis λ2\lambda_2λ2​ can be calculated as:
    • λ1=Emax=12[a+c+b2+c2+(a−c)2]\lambda_1 = E_{max} = \frac{1}{2} [a + c + \sqrt{b^2 + c^2 + (a-c)^2}]λ1​=Emax​=21​[a+c+b2+c2+(a−c)2​]
    • λ2=Emin=12[a+c−b2+c2+(a−c)2]\lambda_2 = E_{min} = \frac{1}{2} [a + c - \sqrt{b^2 + c^2 + (a-c)^2}]λ2​=Emin​=21​[a+c−b2+c2+(a−c)2​]
  • based on the values of λ1\lambda_1λ1​ and λ2\lambda_2λ2​, we can classify into
    • λ1∽λ2,  both  are  small  ⟹  flatregion\lambda_1 \backsim \lambda_2,\; both \; are \; small \implies flat\hspace{1mm}regionλ1​∽λ2​,botharesmall⟹flatregion
    • λ1>>λ2  ⟹  edgeregion\lambda_1 >> \lambda_2 \implies edge\hspace{1mm}regionλ1​>>λ2​⟹edgeregion
    • λ1∽λ2,  both  are  large  ⟹  cornerregion\lambda_1 \backsim \lambda_2,\; both \; are \; large \implies corner\hspace{1mm}regionλ1​∽λ2​,botharelarge⟹cornerregion

Harris Corner Detection

  • plotting the λ1vsλ2\lambda_1 vs \lambda_2λ1​vsλ2​ distribution, we can find the regions for different types of surfaces

  • Harris defines R=λ1λ2−K(λ1+λ2)2R = \lambda_1 \lambda_2 - K(\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)^2R=λ1​λ2​−K(λ1​+λ2​)2, 0.04<K0.050.04 < K 0.050.04<K0.05
  • Thus we get a single boundary for detecting corners

Non Maximal Supression

  • after detecting the cornes using a single threshold, we generally get a cluster of corners
  • we use non-maximal supression to reduce false positives
    • we slide a window k over the image
    • at each position, if the pixel at the center is not maximum we supress it and only reatin those which are maximum

Boundary Detection

  • fit the object boundaries from the edge pixels
    • fit lines or curves to the edges
    • active contours(snakes)
    • Hough Transform
  • some preprocessing is performed to improve the quality
    • i.e. filtering out some oultiers or noisy pixels
preprocessing process

Fitting lines and curves to edges

  • we define the error function(veritcal distance) as
  • 1n∑i(yi−m∗xi−c)2\frac{1}{n}\sum_i (y_i - m*x_i - c)^2n1​∑i​(yi​−m∗xi​−c)2
  • for minmizing the error, we take partial derivatives with respect to m and c, and set them to 0
  • m=∑i(xi−xˉ)(yi−yˉ)∑i(xi−xˉ)2,c=yˉ−mxˉm = \frac{\sum_i (x_i - \bar{x})(y_i - \bar{y})}{\sum_i (x_i - \bar{x})^2}, \hspace{1mm} c = \bar{y} - m\bar{x}m=∑i​(xi​−xˉ)2∑i​(xi​−xˉ)(yi​−yˉ​)​,c=yˉ​−mxˉ
